name: Contrôle de version des workflows n8n dans GitLab avec organisation des tags clients
description:
## Comment ça fonctionne
- Déclenchements manuels ou selon un calendrier (03:00 quotidiennement par défaut)  
- Récupère les workflows étiquetés `backup-workflows` via l'API n8n  
- Normalise les noms de workflows et applique la convention de tag `[client: NOM]`  
- Prépare le JSON dans la même structure qu'une exportation de l'interface utilisateur n8n  
- Vérifie le dépôt GitLab :  
  - Crée un nouveau fichier s'il est manquant  
  - Met à jour le fichier si le contenu diffère  
  - Ignore s'il n'a pas changé  
- Journalise les résultats avec un récapitulatif (créé, mis à jour, inchangé, total)  

## Étapes de configuration
- Configurez vos identifiants GitLab dans n8n  
- Créez un dépôt et une branche pour les sauvegardes de workflows  
- Définissez des variables globales (propriétaire, projet, branche, chemin de sauvegarde)  
- Étiquetez les workflows à inclure avec `backup-workflows`  
- Exécutez manuellement une fois pour tester, puis activez le calendrier

nodes.name: When clicking ‘Execute workflow’
nodes.notes: Manual trigger for testing the workflow execution.

nodes.name: Schedule Trigger
nodes.notes: Runs the workflow daily at 03:00 (server time).

nodes.name: Prepare Workflow JSON for UI-Compatible Export
nodes.notes: Cleans and normalizes workflow JSON to match n8n export format (only required fields).

nodes.name: Clean & Normalize Workflow Name
nodes.notes: Cleans and normalizes workflow name: applies client tag (uppercase) or removes it if missing.

parameters.content:
## 🟨 Prepare Workflow Data 🛠️

### 🎯 Goal
Clean and prepare workflow data for a consistent and stable GitLab export.  
The GitLab file path is always based on the workflow **ID** (rename-proof).  
The normalized name is only used for readability and commit messages.

### 🔗 Nodes
- **Normalize Workflow Name** → standardizes the workflow name and `[client: ...]` tag for readability and logging.  
- **Prepare Workflow JSON for UI-Compatible Export** → outputs the workflow JSON in the same format as an n8n UI export (includes `id`, `name`, nodes, tags, etc.).  
- **Prepare GitLab File Path** → generates the final storage path for GitLab backups using the workflow **ID** (e.g. `workflow_definitions/<workflowId>.json`).

### ✅ Best Practices
- 📂 Always use the workflow ID for file naming to ensure stability, even if names change.  
- 👀 Keep JSON human-readable and re-import friendly.  

### 📤 Key Outputs
- `id` (from exported workflow JSON)  
- `gitlab_file_path` (constructed path based on workflow ID)  
- Full workflow JSON ready for GitLab commit

## 🟩 Gather Workflows from n8n 📂

### 🎯 Goal  
Identify which workflows should be backed up, using tag-based filtering directly in the API call.

### 🔗 Node  
Fetch Workflows from n8n → retrieves only workflows tagged with backup-workflows (filter applied via Tags).

### ✅ Best practices  
🏷️ Tag all critical workflows with backup-workflows to include them in backups.  
🔍 Audit tags regularly for naming consistency and completeness.  

### 📤 Key outputs  
Filtered list of workflows selected for backup.

## 🟪 Start / Trigger & Configure ⚡

### 🎯 Goal
Start the backup manually or via CRON schedule and initialize GitLab + execution variables.  

### 🔗 Nodes
- **When clicking 'Execute workflow'** → manual run.  
- **Schedule Trigger** → scheduled execution (e.g. `0 3 * * *`).  
- **Set Global GitLab Variables** → defines owner, project, storage path, tag filter, execution type & timestamp.  

### ✅ Best practices
- 🧪 Run manually once after workflow changes.  
- 🔐 Keep GitLab credentials encrypted in n8n.  

### 📤 Key outputs
- `execution_type` = `Manual` | `Scheduled`  
- `execution_time` = ISO timestamp  
- [ISO timestamp](https://crontab.guru/examples.html)

## 🟩 GitLab File Management 📑

### 🎯 Goal
Compare the current workflow version with the GitLab repository and decide whether to create, update, or skip.  
The GitLab file path is always derived from the **workflow ID**, ensuring stability even if names change.

### 🔗 Nodes
- **Fetch Existing File in GitLab** → tries to read the current file.  
  - If it exists → passes to **Compare Workflow with GitLab Version**.  
  - If it does not exist → uses the *error output* (On Error → Continue) and passes directly to **Create New File in GitLab**.  
- **Compare Workflow with GitLab Version** → checks for JSON content differences.  
- **Create New File in GitLab** → creates the file if not found.  
- **Update Existing File in GitLab** → updates only if JSON content differs.

### ✅ Best practices
- 📝 Use one commit per workflow for better traceability.  
- 🚫 Avoid unnecessary commits with strict JSON comparison.  
- 🔒 Always rely on the workflow **ID** for file paths, never on the workflow name.

### 📤 Key outputs
- Action performed: `created` | `updated` | `unchanged`

nodes.name: Fetch Workflows from n8n
nodes.notes: Fetches only workflows tagged "backup-workflows" via n8n API.

nodes.name: Fetch Existing File from GitLab
nodes.notes: Fetches the existing workflow backup file from GitLab.

nodes.name: Update Existing File in GitLab
nodes.notes: Updates the existing workflow backup file in GitLab with the latest JSON export.

parameters.fileContent: ={{ JSON.stringify($("Prepare Workflow JSON for UI-Compatible Export").item.json, null, 2) }}

nodes.name: Create New File in GitLab
nodes.notes: Creates a new workflow backup file in GitLab if it does not already exist.

parameters.fileContent: ={{ JSON.stringify($("Prepare Workflow JSON for UI-Compatible Export").item.json, null, 2) }}
parameters.commitMessage:
={{ "Add backup for workflow: " 
   + $("Clean & Normalize Workflow Name").item.json.name 
   + " (" 
   + ($json.gitlab_file_path || $("Prepare GitLab File Path").item.json.gitlab_file_path) 
   + ")" }}

nodes.name: Normalize Backup Output
nodes.notes: Normalizes backup output: adds GitLab path, branch, owner, project, execution type & timestamp.

nodes.name: Set Global GitLab Variables
nodes.notes: Defines global GitLab variables (owner, project, branch, paths, tags, execution type) for reuse across the workflow.

nodes.name: Prepare GitLab File Path
nodes.notes: Builds a normalized GitLab file path for the workflow backup (workflowId + .json)

nodes.name: Compare Workflow with GitLab Version
nodes.notes: Compares exported workflow JSON with the GitLab version to detect changes.

conditions.leftValue: ={{ JSON.stringify($("Prepare Workflow JSON for UI-Compatible Export").item.json) }}

parameters.content:
## 🟦 Output & Logging 📊

### 🎯 Goal
Standardize results for reporting and monitoring.  

### 🔗 Nodes
- **Mark as Created** → enriches each workflow output with `status = created`.  
- **Mark as Updated** → enriches each workflow output with `status = updated`.  
- **Mark as Unchanged** → enriches each workflow output with `status = unchanged`.  
- **Merge Backup Results** → combines all outputs (`created`, `updated`, `unchanged`) into a single flow.  
- **Normalize Backup Output** → consolidates merged data into a standardized schema for logging and reporting.  
- **Summarize Backup Results** → aggregates counts per status and adds execution context (manual/scheduled + timestamp).  

### ✅ Best practices
- 📢 Use consistent logging for dashboards, Slack alerts, or monitoring systems.  
- ✅ Ensure all cases (`created`, `updated`, `unchanged`) are tracked.  
- 🧩 Keep outputs normalized to simplify downstream processing.  
- 📊 Provide a final recap (`created`, `updated`, `unchanged`, `total`) for monitoring and auditing.  

### 📤 Key outputs
- `status` = `created` | `updated` | `unchanged`  
- `workflow_name`  
- `file_path`  
- `execution_type`, `execution_time`  
- `recap` = `{ created, updated, unchanged, total }`

# 📘 n8n → GitLab Backup (with `[client]`) — Cheat Sheet

## 1️⃣ Purpose
- Versioned history, centralized repo, internal vs client separation.

## 2️⃣ Client Management
- Default path: `workflow_definitions/<file>.json`  
- If name contains `[client: Acme]` → `workflow_definitions/acme/<file>.json`

## 3️⃣ Setup
- Create tag: **`backup-workflows`**  
- Tag target workflows  
- Triggers:  
  - ⚡ Manual  
  - ⏰ Schedule (daily 03:00) — or cron example: `30 21 * * 6` (Sat 21:30)

## 4️⃣ Initialization (Globals)
- GitLab owner/project  
- Root path: `workflow_definitions/`  
- Tag filter: `backup-workflows`  
- `execution_type` (Manual | Scheduled), `execution_time` (ISO)

## 5️⃣ Selection
- Fetch Workflows → retrieve only workflows tagged `backup-workflows`

## 6️⃣ Name Normalization
- Extract `[client: Name]` tag → route file to subfolder `<client>/` (or `unassigned/` if none).  
- File name is fixed to `<workflowId>.json` to preserve history across renames.  
- Generate a `display_slug` (optional, from the workflow name) for documentation or index files.

## 7️⃣ GitLab Verification
- Check if file already exists in GitLab.
  - 🆕 No → **Create** (status = `created`, via *Mark as Created*).
  - 🔄 Yes + content differs → **Update** (status = `updated`, via *Mark as Updated*).
  - ⏭️ Yes + unchanged → **Skip** (status = `unchanged`, via *Mark as Unchanged*).

## 8️⃣ Backup Actions
- **Create New File(s)** → first commit of a workflow.  
- **Update Existing File(s)** → commit only if JSON content changed.  
- **Skip Unchanged File(s)** → prevent unnecessary commits.  
- Commit message: "Add/Update backup for workflow: <name> (<path>)".

## 9️⃣ Best Practices
- 🔐 Limit GitLab token scope (repo-only).  
- 🏷️ Standardize client names (`acme`, not `Acme Corp` vs `ACME`).  
- 📊 Add a final recap (`created`, `updated`, `unchanged`).  
- 🛠️ Compare JSON **object-to-object** (avoid false positives due to indentation or line breaks).  

## 🔟 Expected Results
- Only workflows tagged with `backup-workflows` are auto-saved.  
- Internal workflows → `workflow_definitions/`.  
- Client workflows → `workflow_definitions/<client>/`.  
- Clean, structured Git history with meaningful commits and standardized statuses.

nodes.name: Mark as Created
nodes.notes: Tags workflow as "created" (new file added in GitLab).

nodes.name: Mark as Updated
nodes.notes: Tags workflow as "updated" after backup comparison.

nodes.name: Summarize Backup Results
nodes.notes: Summarizes backup results: counts created/updated/unchanged workflows and adds execution metadata.

nodes.name: Merge
nodes.notes: Merges outputs from "Mark as Updated/Unchanged/Created" into a single stream.

main.node: Prepare Workflow JSON for UI-Compatible Export

user.name: Omar Kennouche
user.bio: Automation & AI consultant. I design practical n8n workflows connecting APIs, business tools and AI—focused on saving time, reducing errors and enabling growth.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
